Description: Elongated pottery jar with neck-ridge, crudely made, small handle, flat base; part of neck broken off; broad horizontal red stripes around neck and around body about one third down from the neck. Clay beige orange, somewhat porous, with some medium-sized mostly grey sand inclusions and some other inclusions; Munsell 5YR6/7. Rough clay deposits on surface.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Number "26" written in pencil on outside = EEF Inventory list number. Of the same shape as British Museum 1965,0930.549. Compare the two-handled vessels of similar shape, British Museum 1888,0601.729 and 730. The latter shape is common on Rhodes (e.g. Jacopi 1930, fig. 346; Jacopi 1933, 18-19, fig. 5, tomb II; Kinch 2014, pl. 42 no. 18.1, tomb 18; A. Coulié in Coulié and Filimonos-Tsopotou 2014, 235 no. 69). The version with the single handle recalls vessels found on Cyprus (e.g. Salamis). The production place(s) of these heavy bottles has not yet been determined but must be sought in the Eastern Mediterranean area. Coulié, A. and Filimonos-Tsopotou, M., Rhodes, une île grecque aux portes de l’Orient, Paris. Jacopi, G. 1930. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro I. Clara Rhodos IV. Scavi Nelle Necropoli Camiresi 1929-1930. Jacopi, G. 1933. Esplorazione archeologica di Camiro II. Clara Rhodos 6-7. Kinch, K. F. 1914, Vroulia, Berlin.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (HB.02)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4825 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
